item.description: Connor Schuler's Champlain College Tech Journal.

item.title: Forensic Image Formats
item.description: Raw bit by bit copy Will create the same size, even if disk is mostly empty No additional metadata about the image itself (name, size, timestamps, and other info in the images inode) Cryptographic hashing improved error handling logging performance enhancements (compression) verification checking progress monitoring Proprietary format supports features like metadata, compression, encryption, hashing, and split files Forensic file formats are sometimes called evidence containers Proprietary format from AccessData Supports many features, such as metadata, compression, encryption, hashing, and split files Included all expect features of a forensic format, and additional encryption Open source implementation and extensible file format for storing disk images and associated metadata

item.title: DNS (Domain Name System)
item.description:
Extra . at the end of a website domain www.google.com.
User goes to www.google.com
Web browser checks if it knows www.google.com 's IP address. If not, it asks the operating system. If the operating system doesn't know, it asks a Resolving Name Server Usually automatically defined but might be set manually If the resolving name server doesn't know, it asks the Root domain server. All resolving name servers should know the root name server If the Root domain server doesn't know, it tells the Resolving Name Server to ask the TLD name server (provided by the Root domain server) If the TLD name server doesn't know, the resolving name server asks the authoritative name server (provided by the TLD server) The TLD Domain Server keeps records of all domain's authoritative domain servers. (ie the .com TLD server knows All .com websites authoritative name servers) The answer from the authoritative name server is then cached by the resolving name server, and passed along to the client operating system.

item.title: Storage Devices
item.description:
Four Categories of storage media: Magnetic media Hard Disks and Tapes Non-volatile memory (flash) Optical media. Versions/Speeds 1.5 Gb/s for SATA 1 3.0 Gb/s for SATA 2 6 Gb/s (~700MB/s) for SATA 3 16 Gb/s for SATA 3.2 has card-edge connector Versions/Speeds 3 Gb/s for SAS 1 6 Gb/s for SAS 2 12 Gb/s for SAS 3 22.5 Gb/s for SAS 4 Same connector/interface as SATA, but has separator aka Scuzzy up to 320 Mb/s SCSI-2: 50-pin interface, Molex power SCSI-3: 68-pin interface, Molex power SCSI-3 variant: 80-pin interface 133 Mb/s has pin connector 40-position connector; 39-pin interface IDE drive jumper options Master Slave Cable select Note original jumper setting prior to imaging Standard power connector HDDs has 3 storage sizes: 3.5 in 2.5 in 1.8 in Parts of a drive: ** round flat, magnetic or ceramic discs in a hard drive that holds the actual data Made of two materials Substrate Material Magnetic Media Coating Each platter has two sides sides are numbered starting at 0 Most drives have multiple platters Each platter has tracks, which is where data is stores Most platters have 10k+ tracks Track numbering start at 0 from the outside Stacks of tracks are called cylinders Number of cylinders (tracks), heads (sides), and sectors (aka CHS) uniquely identify the physical geometry of the storage units on a disk CHS also yields disk capacity: Capacity = Cylinders x Heads x Sectors x sector size
Trend toward less platters with more density Each track has sectors 1 sector = 512 bytes (sometimes 4096) and a few extra "info bits" Info bits include ID info, synchronization fields, and ECC data. Sectors can turn bad beacuse of: excessive read/writes some viruses voltage surges Drives have reserved sectors, which are used as others fail bad sectors are difficult to see by normal operating systems, requires special hardware Data on HDDs can be spread out, called fragmentation. Fragmentation increases seek time/delay SSDs use flash based storage and a controller Constant seek time No file fragmentation issues No moving parts no mechanical failures fast startup time no motor noise Lighter weight low power Overwriting process is complicated & expensive read-erase-modify-write cycle Cells have limited life/cycles Wear leveling must be used SSDs are significantly harder to save data from 1 page = 8 sections/sectors (512 bytes) Pages make up blocks
Write is fast But rewrite/overwrite involves additional erasing step Entire Blocks (not pages or sections) must be erased
Grey = unused page blue = in-use page Optimization strategies
Garbage collection
Individual memory cells have limited read/write cycles (5000 – 50000) Like hard disks SSDs have extra capacity not accessible by normal users Unlike hard disks Approx. 10-25% more storage than stated capacity, Overprovisioned areas are continuously used File Deletion on a normal HDD File is marked as deleted in the File system’s database HDD has no clue which sectors are freed up TRIM marks data blocks as stale SSDs need to know this info. Modern OS have support for this command

item.title: Glossary
item.description: Password Manager - A tool to organize and secure ones passwords for online servicesMultifactor Authentication - The use of a secondary device(s) or media(s) for authentication, on top of the typical username/passwordNorman Doors - Confusing or misleading user experiencesBlack Box - Something that you can’t see how it worksICANN - Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and NumbersWannacry - infamous ransomwareInternet - global network of computersThe Web - collection of info accessed using internetStuxnet - first documented virus with real world physical damage, targeted iran nuclear facilitiesIETF - Internet Engineering Task ForceNSFNET - National Science Foundation NetworkARPANET - Advanced Research Projects Agency NetworkThreat - anything that can exploit a vulnerability, intentionally or accidentally, and obtain, damage, or destroy an asset. Vulnerability - Weakness in an information system, system security procedures, internal controls, or implementation that could be exploited or triggered by a threat sourceAttack - Any kind of malicious activity that attempts to collect, disrupt, deny, degrade, or destroy information system resources or the information itselfOSINT - Open Source IntelligenceMcCumber Cube - Represents design aspects for securing data in every level of abstractionHealthcare Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA) - a law that protects the Protected Health Information (PHI).Computer Fraud and Abuse Act (CFAA) - anyone who engages in the following will be subject to consequences ranging from fines to imprisonmentGeneral Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) - a law that protects the personal private data for citizens of the European Union. California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA)  - similar provisions as GDPR for residents of California.Open Systems Interconnection (OSI) Model - Network protocol framework that uses 7 layersGoals of Physical Security – control who can get in, and what they can accessCommon Physical Security Threats – Tailgating or social engineering/impersonationIoT – Internet of Things, often in reference to “smart home” electronics.Geofencing – Only allowing access from specific locationsLeast Privilege Principle - giving people the minimum access required to do their jobs

item.title: Module 3 & 4 - System Security
item.description: Bit-level data: storage, transfer, and bit-level operations of data (input/output, processing) System-level data: roles and authorized resources to be used for reading, writing, and data processing Personal-level data: SSN, username/passwords, address, biometrics, medical history, credit history, background checks, recordings, grades… Policy-level data: Rules how to protect data on all the levels above.  McCumber Cube Security Goals  Information States  Countermeasures (security controls) Data protection laws HIPAA CFAA GDPR CCPA **

item.title: Module 5 & 6 - Cryptography and Ciphers
item.description: Confidentiality: Using cryptography to keep data private Integrity: Using cryptography to ensure that data has not been altered Authentication: Verifying that user is who they claim Non-repudiation: Ensure that user performed activity by proof that they cannot denyNon-Repudiation: Digital signatures, digital certificates. Cryptographic Salt: add a string of random characters to a password before it is hashed and stored to create an extra layer of randomness. Steganography is the practice of concealing information within another message or physical object to avoid detection.

item.title: Module 1 - What is Cybersecurity
item.description: First iteration Arpanet in 1969 Eventually led to worldwide web administered by ICANN First virus documented creeper, self replicating, non-malious 1968: Internet Engineering Task Force created 1990: Arpanet decommissioned, administration given to NSFNET 1991: World Wide Web introduced 1995: private sector takes over internet, NSFNET dissolved 3 policy areas Online rights Cybersec Data privacy Cyber-attack motives Cyber crime Crypto Money Identify theft IP theft Software Designs Movies music Espionage spying Terrorism Propaganda, diversions, etc Hacktivism Defacement, DoS, etc Messing around Each incident in 2020 cost on average ½ million in damages Majority of internet is underseas cabling Data stored in large power hungry datacenters Different countries have different views of network administration US and Allies: open internet China: closed internet with heavy controls in/out
